byline.original: By ABBY GOODNOUGH and STEVEN GREENHOUSE

docs.lead_paragraph: Entering his sun-filled office in Citigroup's Manhattan headquarters, Sanford I. Weill punched a few buttons on a computer near a window before looking over his shoulder and smiling broadly. When asked if he had just looked at Citigroup's stock price, he shrugged his shoulders as if to suggest he could not help himself. ''It's up 35 cents; it's a good day,'' he noted.

headline.main: A Farewell To Citigroup; Weill Built a Giant, A Deal at a Time

docs.snippet: Sanford I. Weill, one of the last classic deal makers who rewrote history on Wall Street, will take his final bow as chairman of Citigroup.

byline.original: By JULIE CRESWELL and ERIC DASH

docs.lead_paragraph: Oil Prices Reach Another Record Amid Concerns on Iran and Nigeria The price of oil futures surged to a record yesterday, settling above $70 a barrel amid concern over Iran's nuclear program and production shortages in Nigeria. While there was no single reason for the increase in prices, oil traders have been responding to incremental developments from producers. With very little slack left in global oil supplies, small disruptions can have a large impact on the market. [Page C1.] Surging energy and gold prices dragged stocks lower. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 63.87 points, at 11,073.78. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 3.79 points, 1,285.33. The Nasdaq fell 14.95 points, to 2,311.16. [C11.] Stocks in fast-growing India are recording unprecedented gains, and now analysts are warning that the market pendulum may have swung too far. [C6.] With oil and natural gas prices showing no signs of plummeting, chemical companies are looking to use coal as a source of energy. [C1.] An Era Ends as Weill Retires From Citigroup Today, at the annual Citigroup shareholder meeting at Carnegie Hall, Sanford I. Weill will cross the stage and take his final bow as chairman. At a time when Wall Street seems to be increasingly dominated by the rise of hedge funds and private-equity firms run by nameless, faceless yet undoubtedly powerful financiers, Mr. Weill is a throwback. He is one of the last classic deal makers who broke many of the rules and rewrote history on Wall Street. Mr. Weill's successor, Charles O. Prince III, the chief executive, assumes the post of chairman today. [C1.] Citigroup reported a 3.6 percent rise in first-quarter earnings as strong revenue from investment banking and operations overseas offset weak consumer results in the United States. [C3.] Prosecutor Challenges Ex-Chief of Enron A prosecutor in the Enron fraud trial bore in on the credibility of Jeffrey K. Skilling, the company's former chief executive, suggesting that he knew Enron was in trouble when he tried to sell shares and failed to disclose his interest in a small company run by a former girlfriend. [C1.] Cendant Set to Name Chief of Online Travel Business The Cendant Corporation is expected to announce today that it has named Jeff Clark, the former chief operating officer of CA, as the chief executive of its online travel business, which includes Orbitz and Cheaptickets.com. [C4.] New Services Field Aims to Keep Jobs in U.S. To help educated young Americans find good jobs that will not be shipped off to India or China, more universities, corporations and government agencies are becoming involved in what is called services science. The hybrid field seeks to use technology, management, mathematics and engineering expertise to improve the performance of service businesses like transportation, retailing and health care -- as well as service functions like marketing, design and customer service that are also crucial in manufacturing industries. [C1.] Study Finds Health Woes Among Katrina Victims Families displaced by Hurricane Katrina are suffering from mental disorders and chronic conditions like asthma, and they lack prescription medication and health insurance at rates that are much higher than average, a new study has found. [A1.] Drug Is Found to Reduce Risk of Breast Cancer Evista, a drug already in widespread use to prevent bone thinning in women past menopause, can also reduce their risk of invasive breast cancer, researchers reported. The drug's maker, Eli Lilly, is expected to apply to the Food and Drug Administration for additional permission to market it for breast cancer prevention in high-risk postmenopausal women. [A18.] University Employees Continue Hunger Strike Outside the University of Miami's main entrance, six janitors and five students continue their hunger strike, with several asserting that the school's president, Donna Shalala, was a union-buster. [A18.] Tyco Agrees to Pay $50 Million Fine to Regulators After four years of criminal trials and accounting investigations, Tyco International agreed to pay a $50 million fine to the Securities and Exchange Commission to settle claims that the company inflated profits by more than $1 billion from 1996 through 2002. Two former Tyco executives who were implicated in the fraud -- L. Dennis Kozlowski, above, and Mark H. Swartz, Tyco's former chief financial officer -- were convicted last year of grand larceny, conspiracy, securities fraud and falsifying business records. They were sentenced to 81/3 to 25 years in prison and ordered to pay close to $240 million in fines and restitution. They are appealing the convictions. [C3.] Slowing of Iceland's Economy Draws Concern An economic downturn in Iceland has caught the attention of critics from outside the country who argue that it faces a financial disruption that could have repercussions far beyond its 40,000 square miles. [C8.] Report Warns of Russian Overreliance on Oil Russia's economic growth is masking signs of trouble that are characteristic of a petroleum-based economy, according to a World Bank report. The report, though generally upbeat, reinforced warnings that Russia is relying too heavily on oil exports while allowing its manufacturing sector to wither. [C10.]

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 9 Die in Suicide Bombing In Israel; Hamas Defends It A Palestinian suicide bomber carried out the deadliest attack on Israel in almost two years in Tel Aviv, killing nine and wounding dozens -- an act that Hamas, which leads the new Palestinian government, called legitimate because of recent Israeli aggression, according to a spokesman for Hamas and the Palestinian Interior Ministry. A1 Plan for Restoration of Babylon Iraqi leaders and United Nations officials are working assiduously to restore Babylon, home to one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World, and turn it into a cultural center and possibly even an Iraqi theme park. No time frame has been given, but what makes the project conceivable is that the area around Babylon is one of the safest in Iraq. A1 Violent Baghdad District Sealed American and Iraqi troops sealed off Adhamiya, one of Baghdad's most prominent neighborhoods, home to hard-line Sunni Arabs who remain hostile to the Shiite-led government and the American presence, after a night of raging gun battles that left homes and storefronts riddled with bullets and at least one civilian dead, Iraqi officials and witnesses said. A6 U.N. Restoration Plan Stalls The director of the $1.6 billion plan to restore the headquarters of the United Nations said persistent objections from the United States were causing delays in meeting deadlines and jeopardizing the future of the project. Approval of the plan would end a 10-year search for space by the United Nations. A10 U.S. to Identify Darfur Killers John R. Bolton, the United States ambassador to the United Nations, said he intended to offer a Security Council resolution that would publicly identify four Sudanese individuals responsible for atrocities in Darfur. A12 Philippine Leftist Under Siege Following a coup attempt in February that he says he had no part in, the government put Satur Ocampo's name on an arrest list, along with those of five other leftist leaders who hold seats in Congress. If Mr. Ocampo leaves the refuge of the legislative building, where the speaker has guaranteed him immunity, he could find himself in jail. A3 China to Reopen Inquiry Chinese authorities, who unexpectedly dropped a state secrets case against a jailed researcher for The New York Times, have started an investigation that could lead to reinstating the charges against him by early May, his lawyer said after reaching a prosecutor for the first time in weeks. A8 Kenya Stumbles in Drug War Something went amiss in Kenya as the authorities tried to burn more than a ton of cocaine seized in 2004 in the largest narcotics raid in the country's history. As officials looked on, one of the two incinerators exploded, bringing the exercise to a temporary halt. It was only the latest setback in the 16-month-old case. A4 NATIONAL A14-24 Evacuees Said to Suffer Setbacks in Health Families displaced by Hurricane Katrina are suffering from much higher than average rates of mental disorders and chronic conditions like asthma and from a lack of prescription medication and health insurance, according to a new study. A1 White House Changes Ahead The new White House chief of staff, Joshua B. Bolten, put the West Wing on notice that potentially substantial changes are ahead in the way that the White House is staffed and operates. A1 Ex-Governor Found Guilty George Ryan, the former governor of Illinois, was convicted in a sweeping federal corruption case. A jury found Mr. Ryan, a Republican, guilty of all 18 felony charges against him, including racketeering conspiracy, mail fraud, tax fraud and making false statements to the F.B.I. A14 2 at Duke Said to Face Charges A state grand jury issued sealed indictments against two Duke University lacrosse players in a case involving a woman who has accused three team members of raping her at a party last month, said Robert C. Ekstrand, the lawyer for 32 of the lacrosse players. A23 Hunger Strike at Miami Outside the University of Miami's main entrance, six janitors and five students are staging a hunger strike. The janitors have been on the hunger strike for 13 days, the students for 6 -- all part of a nasty labor dispute that has turned unusually personal. A18 Drug May Reduce Cancer Risk The drug raloxifene, sold as Evista, which half a million women in the United States take for the bone disorder osteoporosis, can also reduce their risk of invasive breast cancer, researchers reported. A14 Secret C.I.A. Deal Revealed The National Archives signed a secret agreement in 2001 with the Central Intelligence Agency permitting the spy agency to withdraw from public access records that it considered had been improperly declassified, the head of the archives disclosed. A16 Rumsfeld Responds to Critics Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld predicted that calls from retired generals for him to step down would fade away, and he dismissed the criticism as a standard part of the history of American combat. A23 Alabama Seeks Shelter Control Frustrated with the performance of the American Red Cross, Alabama's governor has asked Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff for the federal aid necessary to let the state assume primary responsibility for operating its own emergency shelters in future disasters. A20 OBITUARIES A25 Rabbi Arthur Hertzberg A scholar of Judaism whose contrarian religious and political views and dedication to civil rights found prolific expression in books, articles and essays, he was 84. A25 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 Mayor Overrules Deputies On Welfare Waivers Mayor Bloomberg reversed his own top two social service officials by deciding against pursuing a federal waiver that would make it easier for able-bodied, childless adults to receive food stamps. A1 $2.5 Million Fine for Union A state judge fined Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union $2.5 million for the transit strike that brought subways and buses to a halt and ordered that its automatic payroll deductions of union dues be suspended for at least 90 days. B1 Murder Suspect Surrenders The man accused of killing a 2-year-old Bronx boy who was riding in a minivan to Easter dinner turned himself in to the police. B1 ARTS E1-10 Singer Calls for Impeachment Neil Young, left, who has periodically touched on political themes during a four-decade career, plans to release a hastily recorded new album ruminating on the war in Iraq and directly calling for the impeachment of President Bush. E7 Smithsonian TV Deal Attacked More than 215 filmmakers, television executives and academics have signed a letter demanding that the Smithsonian, a publicly financed museum, reveal financial details of a joint venture with Showtime Networks and abandon it. E1 SCIENCE TIMES F1-10 Heart Disease in Women Puzzling differences have emerged between men and women with heart disease, making it plain that past studies, mostly done on men, do not always apply to women. Researchers have come to realize that to improve diagnosis and treatment for women, they must sort out the differences. F1 Ferrets Face New Danger The black-footed ferret, the weasel with the burglar's mask that was brought back to life after reaching the brink of extinction, is facing a new challenge from the spread of plague in prairie dogs, its only prey. F1 Taiwan Moves Closer to China The island of Taiwan is moving closer to mainland China, pulled by the same geological forces that molded the island's mountains. F3 New Dinosaur Species Found A new species, one of the largest known carnivorous dinosaurs, has emerged from the red sandstone of Patagonia, in Argentina, where reptilian giants seem to have thrived 100 million years ago. Paleontologists reported that they had found the fossils of seven to nine individuals of a species they are naming Mapusaurus roseae. F4 Health & Fitness F6 BUSINESS DAY C1-14 An Era Ends at Citigroup Sanford I. Weill, one of the last classic deal makers who broke many of the rules and rewrote history on Wall Street, is to take his final bow as chairman of Citigroup at the company's shareholder meeting today. C1 Skilling Cross-Examined A prosecutor in the Enron fraud trial bore in on the credibility of Jeffrey K. Skilling, the company's former chief executive, on multiple fronts, suggesting that knew the company was in trouble when he tried to sell shares and failed to disclose his interest in a small company run by a former girlfriend. C1 Record Price for Crude Oil Oil futures prices surged to a record, settling above $70 a barrel amid concern over Iran's nuclear program and continuing shortages in production in Nigeria. Crude oil for May delivery rose $1.08, to $70.40 a barrel, the highest close since 1983. C1 Jobs of the 21st Century A growing number of universities, corporations and government agencies see a bright future for what is being called ''services science,'' a hybrid field that seeks to use technology, management, mathematics and engineering expertise to improve the performance of service businesses like transportation, retailing and health care. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A26-27 Editorials: Mr. Hu and Mr. Zhao; dateline San Francisco, April 18, 1906; counting noses in prison; Verlyn Klinkenborg on Hilaire Belloc. Column: Nicholas D. Kristof. Crossword E2 TV Listings E9 Weather D8

docs.lead_paragraph: When Anthem and WellPoint Health Networks struck their $16.4 billion merger agreement in 2004, California's insurance commissioner initially raised a red flag over the deal's hefty payouts to company executives. He only relented when the two companies agreed to spend $265 million to help improve health services in the state -- an amount the commissioner said was equal to the compensation that WellPoint C.E.O. Leonard D. Schaeffer and other top executives would reap in the deal.

headline.main: In WellPoint Merger, Executives Perks Were Big and Small

docs.lead_paragraph: With a strike deadline set for 12:01 a.m. Friday, the union representing 28,000 workers in New York City apartment buildings has told more than 2,000 strike captains to gear up for a walkout, and many building owners and managers are rushing to hire replacement workers to guard front doors and lug garbage to the basement. The two sides are scrambling to make preparations because, despite weeks of talks, management and the union have made virtually no progress in bridging their differences over wages, pensions and health coverage.

headline.main: Strike Looms For Workers At Buildings

docs.abstract: Service Employees International Union members in New York City plan to strike at apartment buildings on April 21 after weeks of unresolved contract negotiations; talks are to continue; issues of contention are wages, pensions and health coverage; photo (M)
docs.snippet: With a deadline set for 12:01 a.m. Friday, the union representing 28,000 workers in New York City apartment buildings is gearing up for a walkout.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Bloomberg administration, in a significant departure from the welfare policies of the Giuliani era, is pursuing a federal waiver that would make it easier for able-bodied adults who do not have children to qualify for food stamps, even if they are not working. In his first term, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg hewed closely to the groundbreaking changes in welfare policy begun under his predecessor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, who criticized what he called a culture of dependence on public aid and whose reforms were emulated in other large cities. But now Mr. Bloomberg is moving to loosen a major provision of welfare reform.

headline.main: Mayor Seeks to Lower a Barrier for Food Stamps

docs.snippet: New York City is trying to make it easier for adults without children to qualify for aid, even if they are not working.
docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: Officials fear that a new law will prevent poor people who are unable to come up with citizenship documents from receiving Medicaid benefits.
